meanings.def: the type of person you are, especially the way you normally behave, look or feel
examples: You'll soon be feeling your old self again (= feeling well or happy again).
He's not his usual happy self this morning.
Only with a few people could she be her real self (= show what she was really like rather than what she pretended to be).
his private/professional self (= how he behaves at home/work)
He's his usual cheerful self again.
She knew that with a holiday he would be back to his former self.
Her private and public selves were vastly different.

meanings.def: a person’s personality or character that makes them different from other people
examples: Many people living in institutions have lost their sense of self (= the feeling that they are individual people).
the inner self (= a person’s emotional and spiritual character)
a lack of confidence in the self
He was afraid to reveal his innermost self.
a book about reaching for one's better self
a movie about a boy who falls in love and finds his true self in the process
He argues that there has been an increased focus on the self.

meanings.def: your own advantage or pleasure rather than that of other people
examples: She didn't do it for any reason of self.
Self, self, self! That’s all you ever think about!

meanings.def: used to refer to a person
examples: You didn't hurt your little self, did you?
We look forward to seeing Mrs Brown and your good self this evening.
I was very thirsty (note to self: bring water on walks!).

meanings.def: to not have the strength, influence, etc. that you used to have
examples: When his career ended, he became a shadow of his former self.

idioms.idiom: be a shadow/ghost of your former self
idioms.def: to not have the strength, influence, etc. that you used to have
examples: When his career ended, he became a shadow of his former self.

meanings.def: of, to or by yourself or itself
examples: self-control
self-addressed
self-taught
